awd_titl_txt: SSC-CIVIC-PG TRACK B: Streamlining and Supporting Access to Public Assistance Programs in Louisiana
awd_abstract_narration:
Nearly 20% of children under age five in the US live in poverty. To support these children, the US government funds multiple social safety-net programs to provide nutrition, healthcare, early childhood education, and additional income for families. Research on many of these programs demonstrates long-term academic, health, and economic benefits to participating children. However, these programs, which are administered at the state and local levels, are divided among multiple agencies, resulting in separate, and typically cumbersome, application processes. Information on programs and eligibility is neither centrally located nor easily findable, and application portals are often clumsy, confusing, duplicative, and outdated. This can hinder participation in beneficial programs. This project targets efforts to simplify and streamline the application process for families so that children in poverty receive the benefits of the health and education programs for which they are eligible.

This project is planning a centralized application portal for low-income New Orleans families with children, so they can apply for multiple programs that provide services. The project is developing plans to improve and streamline the benefits application process and ultimately to increase enrollment rates in participating programs among eligible families. the project will develop a user-friendly online portal that shows people which benefits they might be eligible for and enables the simultaneous submission of applications and supporting documentation to multiple programs in one application package. The project is working in collaboration with local partners. The portal will be evaluated experimentally to examine the effects on outcomes of interest and understand the causal mechanisms that produce effects.

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program—Track B. Bridging the gap between essential resources and services & community needs—and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE ADMINISTRATORS OF TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND

por.por_cntn:
The planning grant phase of this project focused on building our team, working with community partners to determine which programs and agencies would (and would not) comprise the proposed work, and refining plans for the website and randomized intervention design. As a result of our planning grant activities, we have designed a project in which we will advertise a pilot SNAP application to Louisiana families. Some applicants in this pilot SNAP application will be randomized to see a page at the end of the application that offers to send their application data and documents to two additional programs partnering on this project: the Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC; administered via the Louisiana Department of Health) and New Orleans’ free early childhood education programs (via New Orleans Public Schools). This group of partners—with the Louisiana Department of Children & Family Services (DCFS), which administers SNAP—offers compatibility in timelines, goals, and application systems.

These agencies will then follow up with applicants, inform them about their eligibility for their respective programs, and put them directly into the second phase of the application process, bypassing the often-burdensome eligibility determination step. Another randomly selected (“information only”) group will receive personalized information about these programs and how to apply, but they will not be offered application assistance. Finally, a control group will not receive additional support or information. We will compare these three groups’ application rates to target programs in order to assess the impacts of providing support and/or information.

After consultations with an IT expert, we determined that this approach, using an “anchor program” with a high participation rate (SNAP), would be the best design for long-term sustainability and impact. We identified Code for America as our IT partner and designed the project around Code for America’s ongoing collaboration with DCFS. Code for America is already developing a pilot application for SNAP and other DCFS-administered programs, with the goal of making the application easier and faster for applicants to complete. Because SNAP has a high participation rate, especially for families with young children, it is an ideal anchor program to use as an entry point to help families find and apply for additional programs.

Because Code for America’s application portal is a pilot, we will need to advertise the pilot site to families in order to test the effects of our streamlined application process. Applicants who use the legacy application will not be able to participate. From a prior project, we had access to interviews with low-income New Orleans parents about the barriers they face in accessing public assistance programs. From these interviews, we found that two life events most commonly triggered a new SNAP application: job loss or pregnancy. These findings guided our plans for advertising the pilot application portal during the intervention phase of the proposed project. We will be conducting targeted advertising of the pilot site through health centers serving low-income pregnant people, and through the city’s jobs programs.

We also found from these interviews that parents frequently cited the need to remember login information across multiple application websites as a barrier to accessing benefits across agencies, indicating that a unified portal would particularly benefit applicants if they could use phone number verification to access partner application sites. Therefore, we are building phone number verification into the pilot SNAP portal.

We also found during the planning grant period that fully integrating applications across agencies would be infeasible during the grant period. As our planning grant reviewers suggested, abruptly changing legacy systems is hard. Therefore, rather than request that agencies modify those systems at this time, we opted to build our intervention and randomization mechanism into the pilot portal that Code for America was already building. Although the agencies that receive application materials anticipate developing an Application Programming Interface (API) in the future, it is not necessary for this project. Instead, SNAP applicants in the streamlined application group will have the option for DCFS to securely share their documents with the relevant agency (Louisiana Department of Health or New Orleans Public Schools).

Finally, we designed a qualitative component to this project, in which we will interview civic leaders to determine the critical components needed for long-term sustainability of an integrated application portal. We know that multiple barriers—financial, legal, logistical, and otherwise—may stand in the way of a full-scale, long-run implementation of this portal. Therefore, we will conclude this pilot project by developing a concrete, research-based list of those barriers and civic stakeholders’ suggested strategies to address them. From these findings, we will develop specific next steps in addressing the barriers to building a durable integrated application. 

 


Last Modified: 07/28/2023
Modified by: Lindsay H Weixler
